Cognate with North Frisian hat (â€œhatâ€), Danish hat (â€œhatâ€), Swedish hatt (â€œhatâ€), Icelandic hattur (â€œhatâ€), Latin cassis (â€œhelmetâ€), Lithuanian kudas (â€œbird's crest or tuftâ€), Avestan ğ¬‘ğ¬€ğ¬Šğ¬›ğ¬€â€ (xaoda, â€œhatâ€), Persian Ø®ÙˆØ¯â€ (xud, â€œhelmetâ€), Welsh cadw (â€œto provide for, ensureâ€). Compare also hood.

entries.meaning: A covering for the head, often in the approximate form of a cone, dome or  cylinder closed at its top end, and sometimes having a brim and other decoration.
examples: There was a neat hat-and-umbrella stand, and the stranger's weary feet fell soft on a good, serviceable dark-red drugget, which matched in colour the flock-paper on the walls.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A particular role or capacity that a person might fill.

definitionGroups.group: (figuratively) Any receptacle from which numbers/names are pulled out in a lottery.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, by extension) The lottery or draw itself.
examples: We're both in the hat: let's hope we come up against each other.
The third type of function allows you to check on the state of the joystick's buttons, axes, hats, and balls.

entries.meaning: (Internet slang) User rights on a website, such as the right to edit pages others cannot.
(Cambridge University slang, obsolete) A student who is also the son of a nobleman (and so allowed to wear a hat instead of a mortarboard).

verbs.description: hat (third-person singular simple present hats, present participle hatting, simple past and past participle hatted)

examples: It was truly a breathtaking rise. From the quiet school, Pope Pius XI had jumped Father Verdier over the heads of innumerable Bishops, made him Archbishop of Paris. Soon he was to be hatted a Prince of the Church and put in charge of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame.
